awd_titl_txt: Building Capacity for Interdisciplinary Analysis of Longitudinal Data for Education Policy Research: Understanding Science and Math Teacher Labor Market Pipelines
awd_abstract_narration:
Growth in the demand for workers with math and science skills places competing challenges for K-12 education. Schools are expected to prepare a new and more diverse group of leaders for science, technology, engineering and math (STEM) industries, yet teachers with math and science training are increasingly valuable in the private sector. Teacher shortages, primarily in the fields of math and science, often require school leaders to fill positions with under-qualified teachers. Research is limited on this problem because there is limited longitudinal data linking teachers to individual students or linking teacher labor markets to non-teacher labor markets. As a result, state and district policymakers often lack necessary evidence on how to reform teacher labor market policies in ways that both reduce regional and subject-specific shortages and improve students' access to highly-qualified educators. The University of Texas at El Paso (UTEP) will develop interdisciplinary research expertise in this area by drawing on large scale longitudinal student-level datasets. The project's overarching goals are to develop and link databases for next-generation data-intensive research in education and to build an interdisciplinary community of scholars at UTEP that will continue to analyze these datasets in future research.

The research project will explore three stages of the math and science teacher pipeline: (a) entrance of teacher candidates through preparation programs or alternative certification; (b) assignment of currently employed teachers to classrooms, and their later transfers to other schools and districts; and (c) exit out of the teaching labor market and into non-teaching educational positions or private sector employment. These analyses are facilitated by data on private sector employees in Texas that can be linked to multiple longitudinal student- and teacher-level datasets covering 250,000 teachers and over five million students each year for more than a 20-year period. The research topics that form the basis of this study are: (a) teacher supply, shortages, and the teacher preparation pipeline; (b) access to effective teachers for historically underserved students; and (c) factors leading to teacher attrition. Findings from the study will be of substantial interest to policymakers as well as the academic community.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

por.por_cntn:
The project's overarching goals were to develop and link databases for next-generation data-intensive research in education and to build an interdisciplinary community of scholars that will continue to analyze these datasets in future research. To facilitate the development of this collaborative long-term research network, the research team conducted an expansive study of the math and science teacher labor market in Texas. The study explored three stages of the math and science teacher pipeline: (a) entrance of teacher candidates through preparation programs or alternative certification; (b) assignment of currently employed teachers to classrooms, and their later transfers to other schools and districts; and (c) exit out of the teaching labor market and into non-teaching educational positions or private sector employment. These analyses were facilitated by data on private sector employees in Texas that we linked to multiple longitudinal student- and teacher-level datasets covering 250,000 teachers and over five million students each year for more than a 20-year period. The project?s publications addressed multiple gaps in the literature, filling key knowledge areas that will inform K-12 policy moving forward.

A number of broader impacts stemmed from this work. The project facilitated substantial developments in research infrastructure at the University of Texas at El Paso and the University of Washington and strengthened cross-institution connections. The research team created datasets linking administrative records from state and federal agencies focused on early childhood, K-12, higher education, housing, finance, transportation, and banking. Publications resulting from these data covered a broad array of topics.

To ensure the work reached a broad audience, the research team published their work through policy briefs, editorials, and short reports, in addition to more traditional academic outlets. Most studies pertained directly to the proposed research questions, but others went beyond the project?s main focus. PI Knight used these datasets to publish research on math and science teacher preparation, disparities in access to the most qualified and effective math and science teachers, and math and science teacher turnover in the U.S. and other nations. Other work supported through the development of these datasets included research on high school learning environments, charter school finance, middle school effectiveness, and early childhood interventions. Co-PI Fullerton drew on these datasets to study economic growth, educational attainment, and transportation and trade along the U.S.-Mexico border in El Paso, Texas. Over the life of the award, project leaders mentored 11 research assistants and associates who represented a range of backgrounds and diversity in terms of gender, family income, heritage language, age, and race/ethnicity. All of these research assistants and associates are now working in director or analyst positions in city or state governments or are currently enrolled in a PhD program. Project leaders continue to disseminate research from the project, and the research infrastructure this grant developed continues to support project leaders? work.


Last Modified: 01/10/2022
Modified by: David S Knight
